sources: Encyclopedia.com - Slang, Dialect, and Marked Language
metadata.notes: Extensible dialect marker database for stylometric analysis with feature weighting based on linguistic research

feature_levels.description: Categorize markers by linguistic level for fine-grained analysis

eye_dialect.description: Spellings that look nonstandard but reflect standard pronunciation - indicate informal register, not regional dialect
eye_dialect.note: High eye_dialect count suggests informal register or speech transcription, not true dialect

pragmatic_markers.description: Discourse and politeness markers that vary by dialect

british_hedging.note: British English uses more hedging and softening

british_american.name: ise_ize
british_american.note: Lower weight - both forms accepted in British English

british_american.name: ce_se
british_american.description: British '-ce' vs American '-se' in nouns (licence/license, defence/defense)
british_american.notes: In British English, nouns end in '-ce' while verbs end in '-se'. American English uses '-se' for both.

british_american.name: ogue_og
british_american.notes: Both spellings are used in American English, but the shorter form is more common in computing contexts

british_american.name: doubled_l
british_american.description: British doubles 'l' before suffixes, American does not

british_american.name: ence_ense
british_american.description: British '-ence' vs American '-ense' in some words

british_american.name: eable_able
british_american.description: British keeps 'e' before '-able', American drops it

british_american.name: xion_ction
british_american.notes: The '-xion' forms are largely archaic in modern British English. American pattern disabled as -ction is too common.

british_american.name: gramme_gram
british_american.notes: British English uses 'program' for computer software but 'programme' for TV/radio/events

british_american.name: wards_ward
british_american.notes: Both forms are used in both dialects, but the preferences differ

gotten.description: American uses 'gotten' as past participle of 'get'

collective_nouns.description: British treats collective nouns as plural, American as singular

present_perfect_vs_past.description: British uses present perfect more often for recent events

verb_forms.description: Different past tense and participle forms

shall_will.description: British uses 'shall' for first person future, American prefers 'will'

do_auxiliary.description: British uses 'do' forms more in certain constructions

neednt_dont_need.description: British uses 'needn't', American uses 'don't need to'

quotation_marks.description: British prefers single quotes, American prefers double

period_placement.description: American puts periods inside quotes, British outside (for non-sentence quotes)

titles_abbreviations.description: British omits periods after titles, American includes them

date_formats.description: British uses DD/MM/YYYY, American uses MM/DD/YYYY

time_formats.description: British prefers 24-hour clock, American prefers 12-hour with AM/PM

oxford_comma.description: American typically uses Oxford comma, British often omits
oxford_comma.notes: This is a tendency rather than a strict rule; both forms are used in both dialects

british.expression: at the end of the day
it's not my cup of tea
throw a spanner in the works
